abstract: The acquisition, Google’s largest ever, would turn the maker of the Android mobile operating system into a full-fledged cellphone manufacturer, in direct competition with Apple.
snippet: The acquisition, Google’s largest ever, would turn the maker of the Android mobile operating system into a full-fledged cellphone manufacturer, in direct competition with Apple.

headline.main: Google to Buy Motorola Mobility for $12.5 Billion

byline.original: By Evelyn M. Rusli and Claire Cain Miller

abstract: Carl C. Icahn called on Motorola Mobility last month to explore ways to get more value from its patent portfolio. It appears his request has been granted.
snippet: Carl C. Icahn called on Motorola Mobility last month to explore ways to get more value from its patent portfolio. It appears his request has been granted.
lead_paragraph: Motorola Mobility shareholders are undoubtedly exuberant about Google‘s $12.5 billion deal for the cellphone maker.

headline.main: In Google’s Motorola Deal, Icahn Gets His Wish (Again)

byline.original: By Michael J. de la Merced

abstract: Shares of Research in Motion and Nokia rose on Monday as investors hoped that someone might swoop in and buy either handset maker for its intellectual property.
snippet: Shares of Research in Motion and Nokia rose on Monday as investors hoped that someone might swoop in and buy either handset maker for its intellectual property.
lead_paragraph: Shares in Motorola Mobility jumped more than 56 percent on Monday after the company’s $12.5 billion sale to Google was announced. But it was not the only technology company to see its shares rise.

headline.main: The Ripple Effects of Google’s Motorola Deal

byline.original: By Michael J. de la Merced

abstract: Google’s acquisition of Motorola Mobility for $40 a share may mean the company thinks the best way to make money with mobile computing is by “owning” the device. DealBook’s editor, Andrew Ross Sorkin, speaks to Tavis McCourt, an analyst with Morgan Keegan, in a CNBC interview about what this might mean for competitors.
snippet: Google’s acquisition of Motorola Mobility for $40 a share may mean the company thinks the best way to make money with mobile computing is by “owning” the device. DealBook’s editor, Andrew Ross Sorkin, speaks to Tavis McCourt, an analyst with Morga...
lead_paragraph: Google’s acquisition of Motorola Mobility for $40 a share may mean the company thinks the best way to make money with mobile computing is by “owning” the device. DealBook’s editor, Andrew Ross Sorkin, speaks to Tavis McCourt, an analyst with Morgan Keegan, in a CNBC interview about what this might mean for competitors.

abstract: Google is actively positioning its deal for Motorola Mobility not as a means to buy its way into the handset market, but as an opportunity to buy a portfolio of 17,000 patents.
snippet: Google is actively positioning its deal for Motorola Mobility not as a means to buy its way into the handset market, but as an opportunity to buy a portfolio of 17,000 patents.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Staver/Bloomberg NewsLarry Page, a Google co-founder, left, and Eric Schmidt, the former chief executive, in Sun Valley, Idaho, in 2009.

headline.main: Is Google Turning Into a Mobile Phone Company? No, It Says
